newsitem.title: INDIA: New crop set to dampen India rice export prices.
newsitem.headline: New crop set to dampen India rice export prices.

text.p: Indian rice export prices are expected to fall by an average of $20-25 a tonne with the harvest of the new crop in early October, traders said on Wednesday.
This would make Indian higher grade rice competitive.
But the 25 percent broken variety, in demand in African countries, would still be higher than similar varieties grown in Vietnam and Thailand, they said.
India's five percent broken long grain non-Basmati rice was currently quoted at $310 per tonne FOB, 10 percent at $300, 15 percent at $280 and 25 percent at $250.
"Export prices will fall by around $20-25 when the new crop comes in," said Ravi Kumar of Space Group, a leading foodgrains exporter. "Exports will take place but not to last year's levels."
He said major exporters like Vietnam and Thailand had good crops this year.
"Therefore the exports this year will be split between India, Thailand and Vietnam," Kumar said.
India exported a record five million tonnes of rice in the year that ended in March. It was the world's largest exporter of rice after Thailand.
Analysts expected India to export a maximum of three million tonnes in 1996/97 due to a fall in world demand and uncompetitive Indian export prices.
"The export demand this year is mainly for higher grades of rice," said one analyst.
He said the state-run Food Corporation of India (FCI), the largest foodgrains trading agency, dealt with only the lower grades of rice, demand for which was sluggish.
Vietnam and Thailand lower grades were more competitive than Indian, he said.
He said demand for the upper grades of five percent, 10 percent and 15 percent broken was mainly from the Phillipines, Malaysia and some east European countries.
